item.title: New York Times Connections Hints and Answers for #558 December 20, 2024
item.description:
Connections is back with another mind-bending puzzle that will challenge you. If you want to win, you have very few mistakes you can make, and you might need all of them to get through today's puzzle.

However, if you are completely stuck, this guide is here to help. It has everything you need to win except for the rules of how to play Connections ; it contains category hints, clues to the overall puzzle, spoilers, and a whole lot more.

Words in the NYT Connections Puzzle #558 for December 20, 2024

The Connections puzzle for today contains the words: Whale, Cocktail, Finance, Question, Statement, Solution, Grown, Wine, Tech, Command, Compound, Crypto, Mown, Pharma, Exclamation, and Mixture.

Hints for the NYT Connections Puzzle

If you just want a little hint or spoiler for this mobile game similar to Wordle , you can find it below. Inside these sections are all the hints you will need to get you a win in today's puzzle.

Some General Hints for the Whole Connections Puzzle

Yellow Connections Category Answer

Yellow Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Green NYT Connections Category Hints

Green Connections Category Answer

Green Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Blue NYT Connections Category Hints

Blue Connections Category Answer

Blue Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Purple NYT Connections Category Hints

Purple Connections Category Answer

Purple Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Answers for Today's NYT Connections #558 for December 20, 2024

If you are just looking for the full answer to this New York Times Games puzzle, you can find it below. Open up the expandable section to see all four categories and the words that go into each one.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Connections website, available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: New York Times Strands Hints and Answers for December 20, 2024
item.description:
Strands has a whole new puzzle again today. There is a theme and several themed words, all hidden inside a seemingly-random collection of letters in a grid. In order to win, you need to find all those hidden words, using every single letter in the grid just once.

If you already know how to play Strands but are stuck on today's puzzle, you can find all sorts of helpful details in the article below. Whether you want theme hints, spoilers, or just the whole answer, you can find it here.

The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #292 December 20, 2024

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue Morning Morsel . There are nine things in total to find, including the Spangram and the eight themed words.

New York Times Games Strands Clues

If you don't like the in-game hints in this free browser game because they give too much away, you should look below. Each of these three sections contains just one little spoiler-free hint toward the theme of today's puzzle.

General Hint 1

General Hint 2

General Hint 3

Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands

Each of the next two sections below has one spoiler for this mobile puzzle game, and you can see them by pressing the Read More button below each one. Each of the sections contains just one spoiled word and a screenshot of where it goes in the puzzle.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands

If you want to see the full answer to this puzzle, open up the section below. Inside, you will see all the themed words and a screenshot of where all of these words go in the puzzle's letter grid.

Today's Strands Explained

If you don't get the answer to this minimalist puzzle game, you can check out the section below for an explanation. You can see how the theme and the clue all fit together to make sense.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website, available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Indiana Jones And The Great Circle: All Gizeh Codes
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Safe Codes & Combinations in Gizeh
    • Weather Station Locked Chest
    • Vehicle Garage/Depot Locked Chest
    • Nazi Compound Locked Safe
    • Bright Future Locked Chest
    • Wehrmacht Locked Chest
    • Egyptian Numeral Locked Chest

The Gizeh map in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle has several locked chests and safes hidden around various locations that players can crack open to reveal rewards. However, finding their codes can be a bit of a struggle, as they might require you to solve a mystery or fetch a note from a heavily guarded Nazi camp.

To alleviate the stress of searching for safe codes in this unforgiving desert region, here are all Gizeh codes in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle .

All Safe Codes & Combinations in Gizeh

There are a total of 6 locked safes and chests that players can find in the Gizeh region of Indiana Jones and the Great Circle . While a few of them require you to solve a mystery to get the code, most of them will require exploration in order for players to find a note with the combination written on it.

Here are all the safe codes that you'll need to unlock safes and chests in Gizeh region:

Weather Station Locked Chest

Location

Inside the weather station northwest of Worker's Camp

Code

0609

Contents

Medicine Bottle

Cloud Atlas is one of the first mysteries you'll encounter in the Gizeh region of Indiana Jones and The Great Circle . It involves deciphering radio frequencies to come up with the code for the locked chest.

Vehicle Garage/Depot Locked Chest

Location

Nazi Vehicle Garage south of the Nazi Compound

Code

0805

Contents

One of the Stelae for Nawal

Searching for Nawal's Stelae will bring players to this Nazi garage that has a locked chest behind a truck. The combination can be found nearby, and opening the chest will grant you one of the Stelae.

Nazi Compound Locked Safe

Location

One of the big buildings in the Nazi Compound

Code

40926

Contents

Gold bar and some documents

While infiltrating the Nazi Compound during the main mission, players will look for Voss' office and stumble into a heavily guarded building with a locked safe on the first floor. The code can be found on a note on the upper floor.

Bright Future Locked Chest

Location

Between the Great Sphinx and the Tomb of Khentkawes

Code

0926

Contents

Dynamite that will explode once the chest is opened

This is a chest that players will come across while completing the Bright Future mystery in Gizeh. This mystery can be started by picking up a note in the Nazi Vehicle Garage.

Wehrmacht Locked Chest

Location

The northwest edge of the Nazi vehicle garage

Code

13218

Contents

Money

The Wehrmacht chest is an interesting one to open up in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , as it requires players to analyze the numbers on a hand of cards and input them into the chest. You'll need the Wehrmacht key and disguise in order to access this chest.

Egyptian Numeral Locked Chest

Location

Right outside the Tomb of Khentkawes

Code

3262

Contents

Money and Ancient Relic

Another interesting chest to open up requires players to reference a document with ancient symbols and convert them into numerals that will become the code to unlock the chest.

item.title: 6 FPS Games With The Most Realistic Bullet Physics, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • FPS games offer varying experiences, from competitive environments like Rainbow Six Siege to milsim titles like Escape From Tarkov.
  • Realistic bullet physics are crucial in games like Squad, Arma 3, and Sniper Ghost Warrior Contracts 2 for immersive gameplay.
  • Hunter: Call of the Wild adds physics-based shots, requiring players to consider factors like range and wind for a realistic hunting experience.

FPS games are some of the biggest and most concurrently played games in the modern gaming landscape. Titles such as Counter Strike 2 or Overwatch 2 boast consistently high player counts but offer vastly different experiences, demonstrating the breadth of the genre.

One niche within the FPS games genre is military simulation. These are titles that strive to portray a realistic military depiction, often through their gunplay. Some FPS games offer incredibly immersive experiences through the use of realistically simulated bullet and projectile physics, be they milsim titles or games that simply strive to simulate bullet physics realistically.

6 Rainbow Six Siege

Realistic Bullet Penetration

Rainbow Six Siege is one of the most popular competitive FPS shooters. Loosely set in the Tom Clancy Rainbow Six series, it boasts solid gunplay and strategic gadget use in order to create a complex and compelling competitive environment. This gameplay has resulted in the large Rainbow Six Siege professional scene.

While Rainbow Six Siege is by no means a realistic experience, many of its predecessors did tend to lean towards more realistic gameplay. One realistic bullet mechanic did make it into the game, however, resulting in one of the most crucial gameplay elements. Each bullet does physics-based damage to walls, breaking them uniquely, offering the ability to shape rooms and create unique sight lines using bullet holes and impacts. Bullets also realistically penetrate eligible surfaces, creating a realistic risk to using certain objects and walls as cover.

5 Escape From Tarkov

A Realistic Ballistics System

Escape From Tarkov is generally considered as the pioneering title of the extraction shooter genre. It blends survival, RPG, and traditional FPS elements to create a hardcore PvPvE experience. Escape From Tarkov is wholly unique, with few other games providing the same tension and heart-pounding action.

One of the more hardcore and subsequently nerve-wracking elements of Escape From Tarkov is the ballistics mechanics. Not only do bullets have realistic physics applied, resulting in the need to lead shots and estimate bullet-drop, but the game also has realistic ballistics. Each bullet in the game has unique speed and penetration values, affecting how they travel, how much they break through armor, and how much damage they deal.

4 Squad

Realistic Ballistics & Armor Penetration

Squad is a realistic military simulation title that pits two teams against each other in an objective-oriented PvP experience. Games last for extensive periods of time, and teams must travel across great distances with very real consequences for death. As such, Squad includes realistic milsim mechanics, including bullet physics.

Engagement distances in Squad can be quite far, resulting in the need to lead targets and account for bullet drop. There are also suppression mechanics and an incredibly realistic damage model that can mean one or two shots is fatal. Another element regarding projectile physics is that RPG and Tank shots deal unique damage to vehicle armor based on where they are hit, with realistic deflection and penetration systems in place.

3 Arma 3

Immersive & Realistic Gunplay

Arma 3 is generally considered the gold-standard of military simulation in an FPS title. It includes a plethora of weapons, vehicles, and maps that allow for endless opportunities to simulate military engagements, be they PvP, PvE, or a mix of the two.

Arma 3 operations may last for a long while and often take place over incredibly large maps. This, much like Squad , means that engagement distances are often long and require plenty of forward planning. All bullets and projectiles have realistic physics applied to them, an aspect that is especially heightened over long distances. This means that, whether players are using guns, tanks, aircraft, or mortars, bullet and projectile physics play a key role in the gameplay of Arma 3 .

2 Sniper Ghost Warrior Contracts 2

Realistic Sniper Rifle Bullet Mechanics

  • Release Date : June 4, 2021
  • Platforms : PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S
  • Developer : CI Games

Sniping titles, such as Sniper: Ghost Warrior Contracts 2 , are especially known for their bullet physics. Not to be confused with the other leading sniping series, Sniper Elite , the Sniper: Ghost Warrior series is a long-running FPS sniping series, known for realistic and immersive sniping simulation.

Sniper: Ghost Warrior Contracts 2 is the latest release in the Sniper: Ghost Warrior series, and similarly to its predecessors, prides itself upon its sniping mechanics and bullet physics. The game sees the player sneaking through large compounds and other expansive environments in order to seek and eliminate targets. It features incredibly realistic bullet physics, with the need to pay attention to the wind, range, and other elements in order to land the perfect shot.

1 TheHunter: Call Of The Wild

Physics-Based Shots & Penetration

TheHunter: Call of the Wild is the leading and premier hunting simulation title. It features massive reserves that house all sorts of realistic wildlife that can be hunted, each with differing behaviors and patterns. Players must track down their target using environmental signs, before lining up the perfect shot.

While the Hunter: Call of the Wild is most known for its animal behavior and tracking systems, its ballistic system is certainly an impressive element of the game. Players can use a variety of weapons, most commonly long-range hunting rifles, each with different statistics. Players must pay attention to range and wind direction in order to take their shot, requiring patience and a solid knowledge of the bullet drop in order to hit their target. The game then realistically calculates penetration and entry point in order to determine the lethality of the shot.

item.title: 10 RPGs With The Best Respec Systems
item.description:
Summary

  • Many RPGs now offer respec systems to fix character build mistakes and experiment with playstyles.
  • Games like Cyberpunk, Baldur's Gate, and Divinity offer respec options at different costs and in various scenarios.
  • Dragon Age: The Veilguard sets a player-friendly trend by allowing unlimited, free respecs directly from the Skills menu.

RPGs are getting longer and, for the most part, that's great. In an age of soaring video game prices, value for money is a major consideration for many gamers. However, it also has its downsides. There's no worse feeling for an RPG fan than getting a dozen or so hours into a game they're enjoying and realizing that their character's build sucks and there's no way to change it.

Best-case scenario: this simply kills one's enjoyment of the game as fans are forced to play a character they no longer enjoy. Worst-case scenario: progress is next to impossible as one's character build is completely unfeasible. This is why many of the games with the best progression systems include the ability to respec. Sure, every decision in an RPG should carry weight, but nobody likes wasting their time. These are some examples of RPGs with great respec systems that understand that most gamers have a limited amount of free time.

1 Cyberpunk 2077

A Limited System That's Better Than Nothing

  • Attribute Points can be reallocated once
  • Perks can be changed at any time, at no cost

The current version of Cyberpunk 2077 is a very different beast from what fans got in 2020. After a famously rough launch, CD Projekt Red worked hard to earn back gamers' trust, something they finally gained with the 2.0 update. Among countless other changes, this update added a much-requested respec system. Something the game desperately needed after so many changes.

Cyberpunk 2077 might be one of the best open-world FPS games, but at its heart, it's still an RPG, and it's important to build a character that suits one's playstyle. If fans realize they've gone wrong, Cyberpunk gives players exactly one chance to respec their attribute points . One chance is better than nothing. The game is much more generous with perk points, thankfully. These can be changed at will with no penalties, allowing a certain degree of flexibility. While it would be nice to have more chances to respec attribute points (maybe by paying a ripperdoc), at least this system ensures that character-build decisions still carry weight and encourages a certain degree of roleplaying.

2 Baldur's Gate 3

Rebuild Your Characters For A Small Fee

  • Players can respec their characters after rescuing Withers from the Dank Crypt
  • Each respec costs 100 gold

Baldur's Gate 3 was easily one of the biggest games of 2023. That's hugely impressive when one considers how faithfully it recreates some of Dungeons and Dragons ' most intimidating aspects. It's a 100-hour+ long RPG that can be brutally punishing if the player messes up their builds. The game has one of the best RPG class systems. There's a lot of information to work through when building up one's player character and companions, and it's easy to go wrong.

Thankfully, Larian Studios gave players a way to respec. Early on in their adventure, players can rescue an NPC called Withers from the Dank Crypt dungeon. If they save Withers, they can recruit him to hang around back at camp. He's one of the game's most important NPCs, capable of reviving dead party members and respec-ing them. Each respec of a character costs 100 gold. In the early hours of the game, that sounds like a lot, but by late in the game it's pocket change. As befitting an RPG of this caliber, BG3's respec system balances giving weight to build decisions while also giving players a way to fix their mistakes and experiment .

3 Elden Ring

Give Lucaria All Your Larval Tears

  • Players can respec after reaching the Academy of Raya and meeting Lucaria
  • Each respec costs one Larval Tear

FromSoftware's Soulsborne games have always put a lot of emphasis on perfecting one's character build. They're brutally hard games (for some) that can require hours of grinding if one realizes too late that they've made a mistake with a build. Elden Ring does allow players to respec their character, but they have to jump through some hoops first.

Players can respec after reaching the Academy of Raya and meeting Lucaria. Each respec will cost 1 larval tear, a fairly rare item (there are 18 in the base game and 9 in the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC). The Academy is found a fair way into the game, and it'll likely take most gamers many hours to get there. As an open-world game that embraces player freedom, Elden Ring had to include a way to respec. This one might feel a little restrictive at first, but it fits in with Elden Ring' s difficulty level and still gives determined players plenty of chances to rebuild their character.

4 Divinity: Original Sin 2

The Magic Mirror Gives Unlimited Respecs

  • Find the Magic Mirror at either Fort Joy or The Lady o' War after enabling Gift Bags in the menu
  • The Magic Mirror is free to use and offers unlimited respecs

Before the studio became famous for Baldur's Gate 3 , Larian Studios was most well known for Divinity: Original Sin 2 . Another well-respected CRPG, the game has one of the most open-ended respec systems in any RPG . All players need to do is turn on Gift Bags (a kind of developer-approved mod) in the game's menu and visit a Magic Mirror.

These mirrors can be found in Fort Joy in Act 1 and after that in The Lady o' War. Using them lets players respec every aspect of their characters, turning a mace-wielding warrior into a spell-slinging Wizard if they wish. Divinity: Original Sin 2 can get fairly difficult, especially for CRPG newbies, so this feature is much appreciated.

5 Mass Effect 3 / Andromeda

Respec-ing Is As Easy As Visiting The Med-Bay

  • The player character and companions can be respec-ed using a terminal in their ship's med-bay
  • The first respec comes with a discount but they become progressively more expensive

Repec-ing one's character wasn't always an option in Mass Effect games. In the original Mass Effect there was no way to do it, outside of editing save files, while in Mass Effect 2 , it required reaching a certain point in the story and purchasing an upgrade. Thankfully, Mass Effect 3 and Andromeda made it much easier. In both games, it's as simple as visiting the ship's med-bay and using a terminal to respec Sheperd, Ryder, or a chosen companion between missions.

However, there is a cost associated. The first respec comes with a hefty discount but subsequent respecs become increasingly expensive. The Mass Effect games are almost endlessly replayable, but it's great that changing one's playstyle doesn't mean starting over again. It also makes sense considering the technology of the Mass Effect universe and the franchise's lore, that characters would be able to change their abilities on the fly.

6 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Respec Geralt With A Costly Potion Of Clearance

  • Use a Potion of Clearance to reset Geralt's ability points
  • Potions can be bought from certain merchants for 1,000 Crowns or looted after reaching level 30
  • Receive one free Potion of Clearance when starting New Game +

A big part of playing as Geralt is finding a playstyle that suits the gamer, which means investing ability points in the right skills. But The Witcher 3 is a long game and using the same old skills over and over again for dozens of hours can get old. Luckily, CD Projekt Red provided a lore-friendly way to reset Geralt.

Brewing and drinking potions is a big part of the Witcher lore, and to respec Geralt all the player needs to do is get their hands on a Potion of Clearing. They cost 1,000 Crowns (which isn't cheap) but, after reaching level 30, can also be found in chests as very rare drops . That cost might sound annoying, but it stops the system from being abused, and by the time the player has likely gotten bored of their build 1,000 Crowns shouldn't really be a big deal.

7 Kingdoms Of Amalur: Re-Reckoning

Visit A Fateweaver And Spend Some Gold

  • Visit a Fateweaver in any of the game's major cities
  • Respecs get progressively more expensive based on the player's level and the number of respecs already purchased

When Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning was released way back in 2012, it was kind of a big deal, but it was quickly forgotten. That's a shame because it was a pretty great RPG with excellent combat and plenty of options when it came to building the perfect warrior. The game's story was all about changing fate, so it made sense that the player character could be respec-ed by using an NPC called a Fateweaver.

Each of the game's major cities had one. For a relatively small fee that grew with each respec the payer could reset all of their skill and ability points. The game was never particularly hard, but it was nice to have the option to experiment with different playstyles and use high-end gear your character couldn't previously use. In 2012, it was relatively rare for RPGs to include respec systems, and even now, developers are only just catching up with Kingdom of Amalur's easy-to-use system .

8 Fallout 76

Uses A Controversial Card-Based System

  • Perk Cards can be swapped in and out at will
  • Use Perk Card Machines to pre-make perk loadouts and experiment with builds

In recent years, Fallout 76 has enjoyed one of gaming's greatest redemption arcs. After a notoriously rough launch, the game has undergone updates that have tweaked almost every aspect of its gameplay. What was once a controversial entry in the series is now one of the most popular. However, not everything has changed that much. Traditionally, respec-ing perks and S.P.E.C.I.A.L. traits weren't an option in Fallout games, but Fallout 76 has always used a perk card-based system.

Initially, not everyone was a fan of this system and many fans felt it overly dumbed down Fallout 's already ailing RPG aspects. But Fallout 76's system makes sense for an MMORPG. Throughout their time playing the game, and predominantly by leveling up, players unlock perk cards. These perk cards can either be upgraded (if the player has multiple copies), sold, or equipped. The cards can be equipped and equipped at will at no cost (except legendary perks), allowing the player to essentially respec on the fly. The game encourages experimenting with builds and Perk Card Machines can be used to create custom loadouts. Overall, for the kind of game Fallout 76 is, it's a pretty great system that allows the player to respec at will although unlocking all the best legendary perks requires a lot of grinding.

9 Diablo 4

Pay Gold To Reassign Skill Points And Craft Your Perfect Build

  • Skills can be refunded in the Abilities menu
  • Respecs are free for the first 8 levels, but become more expensive with each level afterward

This one might be a controversial pick, as not all Diablo purists are happy with Diablo 4 's respec system. Respec-ing in the game couldn't be easier. All the player needs to do is go to the Abilities menu, where they'll have the option to either refund single skills points, Paragon levels, or their entire build . At lower levels, respec-ing one's character is cheap, but the costs can mount up.

Since buildcrafting is basically the whole point of Diablo games, many fans appreciated the addition of respec-ing but not everyone is pleased. While the system allows untold build flexibility, it also makes it easy for high-level players to swap builds while grinding late-game activities. That's the kind of thing that used to require starting a new character.

To be fair to Blizzard, they've tried to discourage such behavior. Completely respec-ing a level 50 character would cost 52,000 gold, a cost that could reach an eye-watering 400,000 + gold when including Paragon levels. Pretty much everything about Diablo 4 has been controversial since it was released in 2023, though so this debate seems likely to keep raging on. Still, for casual fans, an option to respec remains much appreciated.

10 Dragon Age: The Veilguard

Respec-ing Rook And Their Companions Couldn't Be Easier

  • Access the Skills Menu and press the Refund Points button
  • Respecs are unlimited and cost nothing

It continues to be a common complaint among gamers that too many modern RPGs lack respec systems. But that trend could be changing. Dragon Age: The Veilguard is the most recent release on this list, and it has one of the most accessible and player-friendly respec systems mentioned here. All players have to do is visit the Skills menu and hit the "Refund Points" button. They can either refund all their points or do it one at a time. No visiting a designated NPC, no tracking down rare items, or shelling precious gold. Just press a button.

Considering a run-through of the game can hit 80+ hours, and most players will spend at least 30-40 hours, it's nice to know how easy respec-ing in Dragon Age: The Veilguard is. This system allows players to experiment with different playstyles and explore the game's extensive skill tree. Hopefully, future massive AAA RPGs will take note and let players respec without jumping through too many hoops.
